docs.lead_paragraph: For a 30-year-old with breast cancer, the outlook was harsh. Though chemotherapy might cure her, it would almost certainly damage her ovaries and leave her unable to have children. Refusing to give up hope, she chose an experimental procedure that might offer her a chance of one day having a family. Before starting chemotherapy, she had an ovary removed and frozen.

headline.main: Thawed Ovary Tissue Yields Healthy Embryo

docs.abstract: Loss of fertility from chemotherapy is common problem for women of child-bearing years; Dr Kutluk H Oktay of New York Weill Cornell Medical Center leads team of doctors in experimental procedure that removes ovaries from patients and freezes them for possible future use; group, writing in journal Lancet, reports on first woman to have embryo created from egg derived from her own frozen and thawed ovarian tissue; embryo did not develop into pregnancy, but odds of in vitro fertilization resulting in pregnancy on one attempt with single egg are not high; Oktay is optimistic that technique could lead to preserved fertility for many women in future (S)
docs.snippet: For a 30-year-old with breast cancer, the outlook was harsh. Though chemotherapy might cure her, it would almost certainly damage her ovaries and leave her unable to have children.    Refusing to give up hope, she chose an experimental procedure that...

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NEW YORK WEILL CORNELL MEDICAL CENTER

docs.lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday morning, Dr. Jennifer Hays went on a television talk show to explain why a large federal study of estrogen therapy for menopausal women had been stopped. As a principal investigator for the study, which found that the drug slightly increased the risk of stroke, she wanted women to know that there was no reason to panic, and she invited viewers to send her questions by e-mail.

headline.main: Up in the Air On Estrogen: Women Under 50

docs.abstract: Estrogen hormone therapy, which was thought to protect post-menopausal women from heart attacks, has been found to increase possibility of stroke and dementia and offer no additional heart protection; Dr Jennifer Hays, Baylor College of Medicine's Center for Women's Health director and lead investigator on estrogen study, acknowledges that there is little data to help menopausal women under 50 decide whether or not to use estrogen; majority of menopausal women under 50 have had surgery and sudden change often causes extreme symptoms; estrogen controls many of these symptoms; Hays cautions that treatment strong enough to reduce symptoms could also be strong enough to do harm; presses for more research in area of horomone therapy for younger women; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Last Wednesday morning, Dr. Jennifer Hays went on a television talk show to explain why a large federal study of estrogen therapy for menopausal women had been stopped.    As a principal investigator for the study, which found that the drug slightly...

docs.lead_paragraph: A young actress experiences great success early in her career. She begins drinking or using drugs, leading to erratic behavior and lost roles. Then, with the help of family and friends, she realizes the error of her ways and enters rehabilitation. Within two years, she turns her comeback into a best seller, then a made-for-television movie. It is, these days, a familiar story.

headline.main: Long Before Oprah, a Celebrity Bared Her Soul

docs.abstract: Actress Lillian Roth broke ground with 1954 publishing of courageous autobiography I'll Cry Tomorrow, which was about her life as alcoholic; University of Georgia historian Dr Michelle McClellan holds that initial change in public perception of alcoholism as disease instead of vice or bad habit was crucial to treating alcoholics; Roth's life described; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A young actress experiences great success early in her career. She begins drinking or using drugs, leading to erratic behavior and lost roles. Then, with the help of family and friends, she realizes the error of her ways and enters rehabilitation....

docs.lead_paragraph: Sneaking off to the kitchen for a cigarette or puffing away on the back porch is not enough to protect other household members from secondhand smoke, researchers have found. Even in homes where smokers made a point of not indulging their habit near others, residue from the smoke was detected on surfaces around the house and in household dust. This residue, the researchers said, could pose a hazard for young children, who spend much time on the floor and explore things by mouth.

headline.main: Run or Hide, Smoke Still Lingers

docs.abstract: Dr Georg E Matt, San Diego State University researcher, leads study that finds smokers who stay away from others while smoking do not significantly reduce family member's contact with tobacco contaminants; study, published in journal Tobacco Control, tested infant's urine for nicotine byproducts and found location of smoking did not influence level of contaminants (S)
docs.snippet: Sneaking off to the kitchen for a cigarette or puffing away on the back porch is not enough to protect other household members from secondhand smoke, researchers have found.    Even in homes where smokers made a point of not indulging their habit...

docs.lead_paragraph: They have become household names SARS, avian influenza, monkeypox and anthrax. But in the not so distant future, said Dr. Julie L. Gerberding, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the public is likely to hear about a host of less familiar diseases and health problems, as outbreaks of such illnesses become ''a new norm.''

headline.main: New Microbes Could Become the 'New Norm'

docs.abstract: Dr Julie L Gerberding, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention director, holds that outbreaks of emerging diseases, such as SARS, are becoming new norm in global health outlook; stresses, in speech to Fourth International Conference on Emerging Infectious Diseases, need for governments to step up preparations to deal with new infectious threats; says that re-emergence of some viruses in regions once free of such diseases is cause for concern and more research; malaria, eradicated in US decades ago, turned up in eight Florida residents last summer; over-use of antibiotics is believed to contribute to development of new resistant strains of infectious disease; photo (M)
docs.snippet: They have become household names  SARS, avian influenza, monkeypox and anthrax.     But in the not so distant future, said Dr. Julie L. Gerberding, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the public is likely to hear about a...

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: Many women have trouble shedding extra pounds after giving birth. But a new study finds that fathers also tend to gain weight after babies arrive -- and the more children, the greater the couple's risk of becoming obese. The finding suggests that eating habits and exercise may have as much to do with postpartum weight gain as hormones or other physiological factors do, said Dr. Truls Ostbye of Duke University, the senior author of the study. Parents, especially those with more than one child, may simply not eat as well or exercise as much as they did before they had children, Dr. Ostbye said.

headline.main: New Babies Add to Fathers' Girth

docs.abstract: New study suggests that social, cultural or psychological factors contribute to weight gain after birth of baby, not just hormonal and physiological factors; study, led by Dr Truls Ostbye of Duke University, finds that fathers gain 4 percent of body weight on average for each child born and mothers gain 7 percent; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Many women have trouble shedding extra pounds after giving birth. But a new study finds that fathers also tend to gain weight after babies arrive -- and the more children, the greater the couple's risk of becoming obese.    The finding suggests that...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dozens of people are scattered about in clusters in this vast bright hospital lobby. Every language and skin color are represented, but we have one thing in common and we all know it: a relative is having a cancer operation, and we are waiting. Hoping, worrying, fidgeting. Trying to read the paper or make small talk. Marching off to the cafeteria for stale coffee or bottles of water that we don't really want. Wondering whether this will turn out to be the prelude to recovery, or to loss.

headline.main: Waiting for News in a Room of Death and Miracles

docs.abstract: Denise Grady article describes waiting room environment in cancer wing of hospital; observes that groups, waiting for either good news or bad news about surgery are as similar and yet as different as patients involved; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Dozens of people are scattered about in clusters in this vast bright hospital lobby.    Every language and skin color are represented, but we have one thing in common and we all know it: a relative is having a cancer operation, and we are waiting....

docs.lead_paragraph: Opening day of the ancient Greek games was a spectacle to behold, a celebration of the vigor and supercharged competitiveness that infused the creative spirit of one of antiquity's most transforming civilizations. People by the thousands from every corner of the land swarmed the sacred grounds, where altars and columned temples stood in homage to their gods. They came from cities that were often bitter rivals but shared a religion, a language and an enthusiasm for organized athletics. There was no doubt in their minds that the games were as much a part of Greek culture as Homer, Plato or Euripides, and on a summer day at Olympia, perhaps more so.

headline.main: When the Games Began: Olympic Archaeology

docs.abstract: Archaeologists, conducting new research on texts, art and artifacts of ancient Greece, are discovering new insights into integral connection between Greek life and athletics; games, which began in 8th century BC and continued for 12 centuries, were both religious and patriotic; Dr Stephen G Miller, University of California, Berkeley, classics professor and author of book Ancient Greek Athletics, describes scene at ancient Olympic celebration; differences between ancient games and modern-day Olympics discussed; photos; map (L)
docs.snippet: Opening day of the ancient Greek games was a spectacle to behold, a celebration of the vigor and supercharged competitiveness that infused the creative spirit of one of antiquity's most transforming civilizations.    People by the thousands from...

docs.lead_paragraph: When a dog sinks his teeth into your leg, it can also take a bite out of your wallet, especially if the injury is not treated quickly, a researcher has found. Treatment for infected pet bites can run into tens of thousands of dollars, according to a report to be presented this week at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons.

headline.main: When Bad Bites Sink Into Wallets

docs.abstract: Study, presented at American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons meeting, finds that dog bites, if left untreated, can be very expensive and dangerous for patient; Dr Leon Benson, Northwestern University associate professor and hand surgeon and author of study, looked at first 90 patients who sought treatment for bites and found 50 percent had to be admitted to hospital to treat severe infection; one-tenth of those admitted paid over $75,000 for treatment; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: When a dog sinks his teeth into your leg, it can also take a bite out of your wallet, especially if the injury is not treated quickly, a researcher has found.    Treatment for infected pet bites can run into tens of thousands of dollars, according to...

docs.lead_paragraph: How sweet it is. I'm referring to the American diet, replete with sweet foods and drinks, commercially sweetened cereals, sodas, fruit drinks and ''ades,'' ice cream, cake, muffins, cookies and candy, as well as naturally sweet fruits and fruit juices. We are all born liking a sweet taste, perhaps to stimulate a desire for breast milk, which is naturally sweet, or ripe edible fruit. These foods are excellent sources of nutrients that support growth and good health. Indeed, as the American Dietetic Association points out in a new position paper on sweeteners, ''By increasing palatability of nutrient-dense foods/beverages, sweeteners can promote diet healthfulness.''

headline.main: In an Obese World, Sweet Nothings Add Up

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses sugars and their dietary value; American Dietetic Assn acknowledges that sweeteners can enhance other nuturient-dense foods and therefore promote healthy eating, but warns that amount must be moderate; daily intake of added sugar from 1988 to 1994 averaged 21 percent of American's daily calories and World Health Organization recommends intake be half that amount; health effects of sugar and types of sweeteners described; drawing (M)
